author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: The Elusive Politics of Elon Musk
description: The billionaire in pursuit of Twitter has often been described as a libertarian, but he has not shrunk from government help when it has been good for business.
content: The opinions poured in, 280 characters at a time, as to whether it was good or bad that Elon Musk had offered to buy Twitter for more than $40 billion and take it private.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: He Envisioned a Nightmarish, Dystopian Russia. Now He Fears Living in One.
description: With eight forthcoming translations of his books, Vladimir Sorokin is gaining recognition in the West just as, he says, Russian writers need to fight back in a semantic war on truth.
content: Over the past 40 years, Vladimir Sorokin’s work has punctured nearly every imaginable political and social taboo in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: The Moskva’s sinking inspires one of Ukraine’s most popular rockers.
description: Vadym Krasnooky, whose band Mad Heads had stopped performing when the war began, said his new song is meant to ‘channel all this hate.’
content: The sinking of the Russian warship Moskva is being celebrated by Ukrainians as an iconic victory, including in a new song by one of the country’s most popular rock musicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova, Neil MacFarquhar and Adam Satariano
title: Where Russians Turn for Uncensored News on Ukraine
description: Telegram is the platform of choice for Russians seeking to escape Moscow’s propaganda web. But can it last?
content: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Russian journalist Farida Rustamova used the Telegram chat app for one purpose: messaging friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: ‘We’re Exhausted’: Palestinians Decry Israeli Raids as Collective Punishment
description: At least 14 Palestinians have been killed in a widespread Israeli military operation in the West Bank, launched in response to a string of attacks in Israel that killed 14 people.
content: JENIN, West Bank — Ramadan nights in this Palestinian city are normally spent staying up late watching drama and comedy series during what is peak TV season, praying or drinking coffee and smoking hookah pipes at all-night cafes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Liverpool Beats City as Endgame Shifts to Risk vs. Reward
description: Liverpool advanced to the F.A. Cup final by beating its Champions League rival at Wembley. But for both teams, every choice matters now.
content: LONDON — In the single corner of Wembley bathed by bright sunshine, Kevin De Bruyne dutifully shuttled up and down. He stretched out his hamstrings and his calves. He made sure his ankles were nice and loose, and, with great time and care, made sure his laces were tight. He wanted everything to feel just right when the call came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Karan Deep Singh
title: India Is Stalling the W.H.O.’s Efforts to Make Global Covid Death Toll Public
description: The agency has calculated that 15 million people have died as a result of the pandemic, far more than earlier estimates, but has yet to release those numbers.
content: An ambitious effort by the World Health Organization to calculate the global death toll from the coronavirus pandemic has found that vastly more people died than previously believed — a total of about 15 million by the end of 2021, more than double the official total of six million reported by countries individually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: War in Ukraine Has Left Eastern Europe Sleepless
description: Mental health professionals across the region say they have seen an increase in patients with intense anxiety. Some are asking for more sleeping pills, and many are making escape plans.
content: WARSAW — For the past seven weeks, Dr. Simona Neliubsiene has struggled to focus on her patients’ charts, distracted by images of bombed cities flashing in her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Will Installing an Induction Range Help or Hurt the Value of My Home?
description: A buyer today may be reluctant to embrace the technology, preferring traditional gas. But this is the wave of the future, and the market will catch up.
content: Q: I am looking to renovate my kitchen, and I’d love to replace my gas range with an induction range. However, I am concerned that when the time comes to sell my apartment in five to 10 years, I will have a harder time selling it since so many people prefer gas. Will induction hurt my resale? Or is induction’s time finally here?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For 700 Years, One Family Has Adorned Pilgrims to the Holy Land With Ink
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 16, 2022.
content: “If somebody wants a Russian star or a pistol or a Kalashnikov, it is not appropriate to tattoo them alongside a pilgrim in their 70s getting a cross.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Horton
title: Peng Ming-min, Fighter for Democracy in Taiwan, Dies at 98
description: He endured Japanese imperial rule, a lost limb in World War II, Chinese martial law and decades in exile to become a leading force for Taiwanese self-determination.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Peng Ming-min, a victim of World War II who endured Japanese imperial rule, brutal Chinese martial law and decades of exile to become a leading fighter for democracy and self-determination for his native Taiwan, died here, the nation’s capital, on April 8. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: A Case for Cautious Optimism, Now That the Markets Are So Glum
description: Stocks, bonds and commodities are already pricing in inflation, the pandemic and war.
content: The headlines about inflation have, once again, been awful. Consumer prices are rising more rapidly than at any time since 1981, and producer prices are soaring as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Days After Setting an Execution Date, a Texas Prosecutor Reverses Course
description: John Henry Ramirez, a death row inmate whose religious freedom case gained national attention, may win a reprieve in an unexpected twist.
content: DALLAS — When a judge in South Texas signed an order this past week setting an execution date of Oct. 5 for John Henry Ramirez, it seemed like the end of the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola, Sopan Deb and Tania Ganguli
title: N.B.A. Playoffs Preview: Good Luck Predicting Anything
description: The Suns have dominated, and the Bucks are the reigning champions. But the Grizzlies, Celtics, Sixers, Nets, Heat and Golden State all have a real shot to win.
content: The N.B.A. playoffs at long last are here. Even though teams dealt with waves of the coronavirus, this was the most normal season the N.B.A. has had in three years. It was the first full 82-game season since the 2018-19 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Subway Attack Proves City’s Resilience Again: ‘We Don’t Have a Choice’
description: The fabled toughness of New York’s residents has helped them power through trauma and tragedy. The shooting this week is another test.
content: Faith Murray’s employer offered to send her home to the Bronx by taxi from her job as a nanny in Manhattan’s West Village on Tuesday. Her boss was worried: A gunman who had unloaded 33 bullets into a New York City subway car that morning was still on the loose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Gary Gensler Reflects on His First Year as S.E.C. Chair
description: “No one could be really prepared for a job like this,” the nation’s top markets regulator said.
content: Almost exactly one year ago, Gary Gensler was confirmed as chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Senate approved him in a 53-to-45 vote, with nearly all Republicans opposing Mr. Gensler, a former Goldman Sachs executive and veteran of the Clinton and Obama administrations who had voiced support for tougher reporting rules for public companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In Cleveland, Some Fans Are Guardians Only of the Past
description: Cleveland’s baseball team adopted a new nickname, and their home opener was the first in years without Native American protests. That doesn’t mean everyone was happy.
content: CLEVELAND — Bill Boldin, a fan of Cleveland’s Major League Baseball team for most of his 52 years, conducted an informal poll on Friday while he waited to meet friends at the Cleveland Guardians’ first home game of the season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Unseen Scars of Those Who Kill Via Remote Control
description: Capt. Kevin Larson was one of the best drone pilots in the U.S. Air Force. Yet as the job weighed on him and untold others, the military failed to recognize its full impact. He fled into the California wilderness.
content: REDWOOD VALLEY, Calif. — After hiding all night in the mountains, Air Force Capt. Kevin Larson crouched behind a boulder and watched the forest through his breath, waiting for the police he knew would come. It was Jan. 19, 2020. He was clinging to an assault rifle with 30 rounds and a conviction that, after all he had been through, there was no way he was going to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Will Democrats Soon Be Locked Out of Power?
description: With a little more electoral ambition, Republicans have a clear majority in reach.
content: Throughout the Trump era it was a frequent theme of liberal commentary that their political party represented a clear American majority, thwarted by our antidemocratic institutions and condemned to live under the rule of the conservative minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Meet the Hot New Houseplant
description: A new “It” plant is here, if you can keep it alive.
content: The nine trailing succulents hanging in my living room are doing fine, not as well as I’d have hoped given the amount of time I spend watering, not watering, pruning and gazing at them. They were supposed to be easy plants: lovers of light, and if not impervious to neglect, then certainly not so fussy that I, a yardless and clueless city dweller, couldn’t keep them healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Good Luck With That!
description: Hemant Mehta returns with a ruminative Saturday grid.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Hemant Mehta’s second Times puzzle and his second on a Saturday. It’s one of those grids that comes together more fluidly than it looks. The two horizontal spans intersect three 13-letter down entries, which all run through a triple stack of (rather bawdy) debuts. Every corner is connected, which makes it possible to get some crosses going and not just pepper your puzzle with an entry here and there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ryder Howe and Tristan Spinski
title: The Battery That Flies
description: A new aircraft being built in Vermont has no need for jet fuel. It can take off and land without a runway. Amazon and the Air Force are both betting on it. So who will be in the cockpit?
content: Kitty Hawk. The invention of the jet engine. And on a frozen Vermont morning, circling above Lake Champlain, the Alia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Kashmir Journalists Face Forbidding Pattern: Arrest, Bail, Rearrest
description: The practice, employed against at least three journalists in the restive region, is being used to limit free speech and chill news reporting, activists say.
content: After being held in jail for close to four years awaiting trial on charges of aiding militants, the Kashmiri journalist Aasif Sultan was granted bail by the courts last week, and he thought he could finally return home to his wife and his daughter, who was just 6 months old when he was arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: From Her First $100K to 3 Million Followers
description: Tori Dunlap’s savings journey turned her into a full-time finfluencer. Her latest partnership aims to help women get together and get started with investing.
content: The women logged on from Alaska, Florida and points in between, excited and nervous. The energy was palpable in the chat stream, which bubbled with the kind of quick and candid confessions that emerge in a room of virtual strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
description: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.
content: Russia pounded military targets throughout Ukraine on Saturday, in apparent retaliation for the sinking of an important naval ship and in preparation for an offensive in the Donbas region of the country’s east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: A Russian Default Is Looming. A Bitter Fight Is Likely to Follow.
description: The ultimate arbiter of a sovereign default is an open question but markets may have the final word.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia is ambling toward a major default on its foreign debt, a grim milestone that it has not seen since the Bolshevik Revolution more than a century ago and one that raises the prospect of years of legal wrangling and a global hunt by bondholders for Russian assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Save America’s Patent System
description: It needs to promote innovation, not reward legal trickery.
content: The injector pen is not, by any stretch, a new invention. Drugmakers of every ilk have been using it for decades to deliver all sorts of crucial medications into the bloodstream. By adding this old technology to its insulin drug, Glargine, however, the pharmaceutical giant Sanofi was nonetheless able to secure additional patents for a lucrative product. The drug’s existing patents were expiring, and new ones enabled the company to maintain its monopoly — and the bounty that goes with it — much longer. But for the patients who depend on this life-sustaining drug? Too many are still struggling to afford it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: On Japan’s Adorable ‘Old Enough!’ Show and the State of American Childhoods
description: Let’s take a few baby steps toward teaching our kids independence.
content: An aggressively adorable reality show that’s been on for decades in Japan recently hit Netflix. It’s called “Old Enough!” and it depicts Japanese little ones, some as young as 2, taking their first solo journeys (the show’s original title is translated as “My First Errand”). These tiny children are shown toddling by themselves to the grocery store, to their grandmother’s house to pick something up or to a local farm to yank an enormous cabbage out of the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: In Quebec, the Clash Over Caribou Heats Up
description: Canada is threatening to use, for the first time, a provision in endangered species legislation to intervene and force caribou habitat protection in Quebec.
content: They are known as “gray ghosts,” roaming silently and in sparse herds through Canada’s boreal forests and mountains. They dash out of view almost as suddenly as they appear, for the few lucky enough to spot them. The animal is so beloved in Canada that it is embossed on the 25 cent coin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump’s Focus on 2020 Election Splits Michigan Republicans
description: The former president is trying to reshape the battleground state in his image. But his false claims about the 2020 election are driving a wedge between loyalists and those who are eager to move on.
content: SHELBY TOWNSHIP, Mich. — The shouting in the banquet hall erupted just minutes after the Macomb County Republican Party convention was called to order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Gearhart
title: Benson Kipruto’s Unlikely Journey to Boston Marathon Champion
description: Competitive running was a fallback career for the Kenyan. Now he is aiming for back-to-back Boston Marathon wins.
content: MOSORIOT, Kenya — Feet lightly clap on an empty road just after sunrise on Sunday, 15 days out from the 126th Boston Marathon. Benson Kipruto, the Kenyan runner, is pounding out miles in the small town of Mosoriot, just past the rusty blue arch at the border of Nandi County that is known as the Source of Champions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Travel’s ‘Great Comeback’ Has a Price: Chaos
description: In recent weeks, travelers on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean have endured long lines at airports, flight delays or cancellations, and plenty of frustration. Is this the new normal?
content: Arriving at London’s Gatwick Airport for his easyJet flight to Malaga, Spain, with his wife and 12-year-old daughter on April 4, Alasdair Crawley said it was like walking into the mayhem of the aftermath of a soccer game. The 49-year-old plumber from East London described long unruly lines of angry passengers trying to determine the status of their flights and families sprawled out across the floor eating, drinking and sleeping to get through long delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Activision tells regulators it will cooperate with insider trading investigation.
description: The company received requests for information that appeared to relate to investigations into whether investors who knew Bobby Kotick, the chief executive, traded Activision stock before a deal with Microsoft was made public.
content: Activision Blizzard, the video game maker set to be sold to Microsoft for nearly $70 billion, said in a legal filing on Friday that it would cooperate with an investigation into whether some of the company’s investors engaged in insider trading before the deal’s announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eitan Nechin
title: Overlooked No More: Jacqueline Shohet Kahanoff, Writer of Levantine Identity
description: In her books and essays, she developed a social model and a vision for how various groups could find their place in a modern Middle East.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Art Rupe, Who Brought Rhythm and Blues to the Mainstream, Dies at 104
description: As the founder of the independent label Specialty Records, he helped set the table for the rock ’n’ roll era by signing performers like Little Richard.
content: Art Rupe, the founder of Specialty Records, an innovative independent label based in Los Angeles that brought rhythm and blues into the mainstream and helped set the table for the rock ’n’ roll era with singers like Little Richard and Lloyd Price, died on Friday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 104.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Nazi Soldier Stole a Watch in 1942. It Turned Up 80 Years Later.
description: The watch, made as a gift in 1910, has been returned to the maker’s family in the Netherlands. It still works.
content: After nearly 80 years, a watch that was taken by a Nazi soldier during World War II, lost in a cornfield and later hidden in a clock on a farm in Belgium has been returned to the grandchildren of its maker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Hume Kennerly
title: Photographing Hell
description: Some images will always have the power to make us confront horror.
content: The following images depict graphic violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Macron Vows Ambitious Green Policies, Wooing the Left in Runoff
description: France’s president is trying to tap into the country’s large pool of left-wing voters, but many are hesitant to back him.
content: MARSEILLE, France — On a stage erected on lush green lawns overlooking the sun-soaked Mediterranean port of Marseille, President Emmanuel Macron declared on Saturday to a crowd of supporters, “The politics that I will carry out in the next five years will be environmental, or will not be!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Amid Backlash, Texas Governor Repeals Border-Clogging Immigration Order
description: Gov. Greg Abbott said he would reissue the policy, under which all commercial vehicles arriving at the border were inspected, if illegal crossings into Texas increased.
content: Facing an intensifying backlash from political parties and business groups, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Friday ended his policy of inspecting all commercial vehicles crossing into the state from Mexico, a time-consuming process that had caused traffic jams of 14 hours or more at the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: How Loathing Golf Taught Me to Confront My Own Prejudice
description: The game symbolized things I wanted to do but could never afford.
content: If you are a regular reader of this newsletter, you are probably aware that I’m a pretty big fan of sports. Football, of course, but also basketball, gymnastics, weight lifting, rugby — almost any physical game played by humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Some Care Workers Are Seeing a Bump in Pay. They’re Working to Make It Last.
description: Care workers are organizing for better work conditions and to keep pandemic gains going.
content: Sandra Rosales’s voice takes on an affectionate lilt when she recalls the notes she received from the two girls she used to care for in Brooklyn. “If I had to describe you in one word it would be loving,” one of her nanny charges, now 9, wrote to Ms. Rosales last year. “Thanks for encouraging me to be brave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Manager
description: Rachel Balkovec outworked and out-studied the competition for years. Now, at the helm of the Tampa Tarpons, she is ready to change baseball, one player at a time.
content: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Somewhere over Tampa Bay, while driving on the causeway connecting Tampa to Clearwater, Fla., Rachel Balkovec asked the two top Yankees prospects in the back seat if they had ever watched softball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: We Have a Creativity Problem
description: Outwardly, we praise innovation. Inwardly, we harbor a visceral aversion to it, studies have found.
content: Creativity is lauded as vital, and seen as the lifeblood of great entertainment, innovation, progress and forward-thinking ideas. Who doesn’t want to be creative or to hire inventive employees?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay and Clara Vannucci
title: In Venice, a Young Boatman Steers a Course of His Own
description: “What I ask myself all the time is, ‘What is a man?’” says Edoardo Beniamin, a trans man training to join his father’s profession as a gondolier.
content: VENICE, Italy — From the time he was a child, Edoardo Beniamin could envision paddling a gondola through the waterways of Venice, his native city. He saw himself, dressed in a striped jersey and ribboned straw hat, following his father and an uncle into a profession that has served as the enduring symbol of La Serenissima for a thousand years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Still Feeling the Bern
description: Bernie Sanders lost the Democratic nomination, but won the soul of the party.
content: WASHINGTON — Ari Rabin-Havt could not stop smiling in the winter of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Fedor, Vimal Patel and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 10 People Wounded in South Carolina Mall Shooting, Police Say
description: The police said that the shooting, at the Columbiana Centre mall in Columbia, S.C., was not random and that three people had been detained.
content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A holiday weekend was punctured by violence as 10 people were shot at a crowded South Carolina mall on Saturday and two others were injured in an ensuing stampede during the gunfire, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Andy Newman
title: Son of Author Paul Auster Charged in Fatal Overdose of 10-Month-Old Daughter
description: Daniel Auster was charged with manslaughter after the medical examiner determined the girl’s cause of death was an overdose of fentanyl and heroin, the police said.
content: A 10-month-old girl in Brooklyn died from a combination of fentanyl and heroin, and her 44-year-old father, Daniel Auster — son of the famous novelist Paul Auster — was charged in her death, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson, Ashley Southall and Andy Newman
title: After a Gunman Seemed to Vanish, These New Yorkers Helped End the Search
description: Witnesses, video, police accounts and court records depict a troubled man’s carefully planned attack, and the lucky breaks he seized to melt back into the city.
content: The man lumbered into the Kings Highway subway station in Brooklyn, wearing a yellow hard hat and reflective safety jacket, dragging a rolling duffel bag and clutching a backpack. He swiped his MetroCard at a turnstile, and when it didn’t let him through, he flagged the agent in a nearby booth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Public Foots Most of the $1.4 Billion for a Stadium. Buffalo Fans Cheer.
description: Critics have savaged the deal, which would use $850 million in state and local funds. But many in the city say keeping the Bills in Buffalo is good for civic pride.
content: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — Just like the Buffalo Bills themselves, who famously lost four straight Super Bowls, there is no question that the team’s new $1.4 billion stadium proposal has its doubters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: How a Lone Tenant Is Holding Up a $70 Million Condo Deal
description: Ahmet Nejat Ozsu has refused to leave his apartment on the Upper West Side, delaying a plan for condominiums. A pandemic remedy for renters could help him prolong the standoff.
content: Ahmet Nejat Ozsu won’t budge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty and Jeanna Smialek
title: The Sky-High Pandemic Housing Market Finds Gravity Does Exist
description: Mortgage costs have jumped as the Federal Reserve has raised rates. With higher rates come fewer offers.
content: Luis Solis, a real estate agent in Portland, Ore., marked a milestone weekend late last month. It was the first time in two years that one of his listings made it to Monday without any offers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz
title: Putin’s Ukraine Gamble Pivots to a Very Different Battlefield
description: After Russian forces were mauled in cities and towns in northern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is shifting the focus of his invasion to the flatlands of Donbas, in the east.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — There are fields instead of city streets, farmsteads instead of apartment buildings. Open highways stretch to the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: On the Hunt
description: Let’s crack open Emet Ozar’s colorful debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Once you’ve finished this grid, you’ll wonder how it is that its theme had never been used in a puzzle before; still, it’s fabulous that it hatched from the mind of a new Times constructor, and not some hard-boiled veteran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Paul Siebel, Singer Whose Career Was Notable but Brief, Dies at 84
description: He arrived on the Greenwich Village folk scene in the mid-1960s and drew comparisons to Dylan. But he left the music business not long after.
content: Paul Siebel, a folk singer and songwriter who drew comparisons to Bob Dylan in the 1960s and ’70s but dropped out of the music business, hindered by stage fright and disappointed by the lack of attention his work received, died on April 5 in hospice care in Centreville, Md. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: The Fiddle Leaf Fig Is Dead
description: Meet the man working to put the next big “It” plant on every windowsill in North America.
content: Mike Rimland, the “plant hunter” for Costa Farms, one of the largest houseplant growers in North America, was touring a tiny nursery in Southeast Asia about five years ago when he spotted a bunch of dark purple waxy leaves he didn’t recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Scene: At a Passover Seder in Krakow
description: Ukrainian refugees are attending Passover Seders, revisiting the Jewish story of flight as they themselves live as refugees.
content: Ukrainian refugees are attending Passover Seders, revisiting the Jewish story of flight as they themselves live as refugees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: 10 Wounded in South Carolina Mall Shooting, Police Say
description: Ten people were shot at a mall in Columbia, S.C., and two others were hurt in an ensuing stampede, the police said. Officials said that the shooting was not random and that three people had been detained.
content: Ten people were shot at a mall in Columbia, S.C., and two others were hurt in an ensuing stampede, the police said. Officials said that the shooting was not random and that three people had been detained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Missiles Hit Central Kharkiv
description: Officials said at least two civilians were killed and 18 others were wounded in a missile strike in Kharkiv, Ukraine, that destroyed homes and shops.
content: Officials said at least two civilians were killed and 18 others were wounded in a missile strike in Kharkiv, Ukraine, that destroyed homes and shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
title: As Russia Pivots East, Ukrainians Ask: Are We Next?
description: Our cameras captured life on the front lines in southeast Ukraine, where Russian shelling is relentless and it feels like the war is inching closer every day.
content: Our cameras captured life on the front lines in southeast Ukraine, where Russian shelling is relentless and it feels like the war is inching closer every day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 16, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 16, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about a Soviet-era air defense system sent to Ukraine by Slovakia misspelled the given name of the mayor of Dobra, Slovakia. He is Mikulas Csoma, not Mikolas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should More Students Skip College?
description: Readers discuss John McWhorter’s suggestion that ending high school after 10th grade and skipping college are better options for some students.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
